title: Lab 0: Introduction to the ESP32-C6-DevKit1
description: This introductory lab guides you through picking up your ESP32-C6-DevKit1 board, setting up the Arduino IDE with necessary libraries and board managers, and running your first program to verify your hardware is working correctly.
content: This introductory lab guides you through picking up your ESP32-C6-DevKit1 board, setting up the Arduino IDE with necessary libraries and board managers, and running your first program to verify your hardware is working correctly.

content.content: Welcome to the world of embedded systems! In this course, you will be working with the ESP32-C6-DevKit1, a powerful microcontroller that you'll use throughout the semester. This first lab is focused on getting your board and ensuring you can properly set up the Arduino IDE with the necessary libraries and board managers. You'll need these skills throughout the semester as you work on various projects with your ESP32-C6 board.

This lab is split up into 2 parts:

1. You must go to Van Leer C256/252 when a TA or Diego is present to check out your ESP32-C6 board. You will be given a label to stick on the bottom of the board to identify and the TA will note down which board you got. Then, following the instructions provided, you will load a simple program to run on the board.

2. The second part of the lab is answering the questions on the Canvas Quiz.

By the end of this lab, you will be able to:
- Obtain your ESP32-C6-DevKit1 board that you'll use throughout the semester.
- Install and configure the Arduino IDE for ESP32-C6 development.
- Install the necessary board manager for the ESP32-C6.
- Install the Adafruit NeoPixel library.
- Compile and upload a program to make the onboard LED flash red.
- Understand the basic process of programming your ESP32-C6 board.

**Hardware:**
* ESP32-C6-DevKit1 Board (to be checked out from Van Leer C256/252)
* A USB-C cable capable of data transfer (not just charging)

**Software:**
* Arduino IDE (pre-installed on lab computers or install on your own device)
* ESP32 board manager by Espressif
* Adafruit NeoPixel library

sections.title: Part 1: Board Checkout and Arduino IDE Setup

content.content:
**Step 1: Board Checkout**

1. Go to Van Leer C256/252 when a TA or Diego is present.
2. You will be given an ESP32-C6-DevKit1 board and a label to stick on the bottom for identification.
3. The TA will note down which board you received.

**Step 2: Arduino IDE Setup**

1. Open the Arduino IDE on the lab computer (or install it on your own device if needed).
2. Go to Boards Manager on the left-hand side of the IDE.
3. Type "esp32" in the search box.
4. Install the esp32 board manager by Espressif. Make sure to install the latest version.

content.caption: Screenshot 2025-08-22 134429.png - Installing the ESP32 board manager

content.content:
**Step 3: Install Required Library**

1. Go to the Library Manager on the left-hand side of the Arduino IDE.
2. Search for "Adafruit NeoPixel".
3. Install the Adafruit NeoPixel library.

content.caption: Screenshot 2025-08-22 140239.png - Installing the Adafruit NeoPixel library

content.content:
**Step 4: Configure the Board**

1. Go to the top of the Arduino IDE and select Tools -> Board -> esp32 -> ESP32C6 Dev Module.
2. This will tell the Arduino IDE which specific board you are using.
Make sure you plug the USB-C cable into the "USB" port on the ESP32-C6-DevKit1, not the "UART" port. If correctly plugged in, you may see the onboard LED cycle between many different colors.

1. Press the upload button in the top left of the Arduino IDE (the arrow button between the checkmark and triangle icon buttons).
2. If everything is set up correctly, the onboard LED will flash red.
3. Once the LED is flashing red, show it to a UTA to get checked off for this part of the lab.
The second part of this lab involves answering questions on a Canvas Quiz. After completing the hardware portion of the lab, proceed to complete the quiz on Canvas.

If you are working with a partner, make sure you are both present in the lab room to complete the first part and go through the Canvas Quiz together. However, you both need to submit your own quiz individually, as Canvas doesn't allow group quiz submissions.
